original_title: Sri Lanka bond yields plunge 10 to 12-pct without DDR premium
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s bond yields dropped 10 to 12 percent across multiple maturities in a historic fall on Tuesday, dealers said after bank and private bonds were excluded from a domestic debt restructuring.

Sri Lanka’s bond yields have risen to around 20 percent in the wake of previous currency crises triggered by the island’s soft pegged (flexible exchange rate) central bank, but this year they rose to around 28-30 percent due to fears of domestic debt restructuring.

Due to a flaw in the IMF’s default workout framework, an early cut off date is not announced. Sri Lanka’s officials partially solved the problem by publicly saying Treasury bills were excluded from domestic re-structuring.
A bond maturing on 01.07.2025 was quoted at 14.25/15.75 percent down from 28.00/29.00 percent last week, on June 28, dealers said.
A bond maturing on 15.09.2027 was quoted at 14.50/15.00 percent down from 25.25/26.00 percent .
A 15.05.2026 bond was quoted at 14.75/15.50. It was traded around 27.50 traded last week.
A 01.05.2027 bond was quoted at 14.50/15.00 – down from 24.50/25.50 last week.
A 15.09.2027 bond was quoted at 14.50/15.00 percent down from 25.25/26.00 percent.
The rupee was quoted at 306/308 to the US dollar in the interbank market. (Colombo/July01/2023)
